user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectFdClear:
```c
int32 OS_SelectFdClear(OS_FdSet *Set, osal_id_t objid)
{
    int32        return_code;
    osal_index_t local_id;

    /* check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, objid, &local_id);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * Clears the bit in the uint8 object_ids array that corresponds
         * to the local_id where local_id >> 3 determines the array element,
         * and the mask/shift clears the bit within that element.
         */
        Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] &= ~(1 << (local_id & 0x7));
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SelectFdClear:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t object_id, osal_index_t *ArrayIndex)
{
    uint32         max_id;
    uint32         obj_index;
    osal_objtype_t actual_type;
    int32          return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(ArrayIndex);

    obj_index   = OS_ObjectIdToSerialNumber_Impl(object_id);
    actual_type = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id);

    /*
     * If requested by the caller, enforce that the ID is of the correct type.
     * If the caller passed OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED, then anything is allowed.
     */
    if (idtype != OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED && actual_type != idtype)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }
    else
    {
        max_id = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(actual_type);
        if (max_id == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            *ArrayIndex = OSAL_INDEX_C(obj_index % max_id);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06
...
void OS_printf(const char *String, ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    msg_buffer[OS_BUFFER_SIZE];
    int     actualsz;

    BUGCHECK_VOID(String != NULL)

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        /*
         * Catch some historical mis-use of the OS_printf() call.
         *
         * Typically OS_printf() should NOT be called before OS_API_Init().
         *
         * This was never guaranteed to work, particularly on a VxWorks
         * deployment where the utility task was enabled.
         *
         * However, some PSPs do this, particularly those that used POSIX
         * where it happened to work (because OS_printf just called printf).
         *
         * As a workaround, use the OS_DEBUG facility to dump the message,
         * along with a clue that this API is being used inappropriately.
         *
         * If debugging is not enabled, then this message will be silently
         * discarded.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("BUG: OS_printf() called when OSAL not initialized: %s", String);
    }
    else if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfEnabled)
    {
        /* Format and determine the size of string to write */
        va_start(va, String);
        actualsz = vsnprintf(msg_buffer, sizeof(msg_buffer), String, va);
        va_end(va);

        if (actualsz < 0)
        {
            /* unlikely: vsnprintf failed */
            actualsz = 0;
        }
        else if (actualsz >= OS_BUFFER_SIZE)
        {
            /* truncate */
            actualsz = OS_BUFFER_SIZE - 1;
        }

        msg_buffer[actualsz] = 0;

        OS_ConsoleWrite(OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfConsoleId, msg_buffer);
    }
}
...
#define OS_INVALID_POINTER (-2)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not listed are plain constant definitions, simple assignments or returns, or single-line operations that do not by themselves indicate unreachable code. The selected fragments are control-flow points or macros that can cause non-local exits or branches that could be impossible/redundant depending on macro definitions or runtime invariants: - OS_CHECK_POINTER / BUGCHECK macros (their implementation may perform non-local exit or be no-ops) can make subsequent code unreachable in some configurations. - The if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) block in OS_SelectFdClear depends on the possible return values of OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex; if that call can never return success for the provided idtype/object_id domain, the block would be unreachable. - The conditional branches in OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex (type-check branch, max_id == 0 branch, and success branch that writes *ArrayIndex) are control-flow paths that may be unreachable depending on OS_GetMaxForObjectType, ObjectId-to-type mapping, or caller expectations. - The OS_printf initial BUGCHECK_VOID and the subsequent GlobalState / PrintfEnabled branches are runtime-control branches that may be permanently true/false depending on initialization code. Other lines such as simple macro constant definitions (#define OS_SUCCESS (0), #define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06), plain variable declarations, and single return statements do not by themselves indicate unreachable code and thus were not included.
